newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: FEATURE - Unrest casts long shadow over Albania economy.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Unrest casts long shadow over Albania economy.

text.p: Little over a year ago Albania seemed a relatively safe bet in a Balkan region ravaged by war and political instability.
Now, Europe's poorest country is mired in political and economic chaos just as the hard-won peace in former Yugoslavia holds out a fragile hope of renewal for its neighbours.

Western investment in Albania, estimated at a modest $250 million from 1992 to 1996, has all but dried up since January when violent insurrections flared in the south, later spreading north and even briefly engulfing the capital.

"Obviously there has been a serious change in the distribution of power. This is just the beginning of a troublesome and unstable phase," said Vladimir Gligorov, Albania expert at the Vienna Institute for Comparative Studies.

Tirana's Rinasi airport, its single runway under reconstruction by Siemens AG with the aid of a 48 million mark ($28.3 million) soft credit from Germany, closed to traffic last week, forcing foreign nationals to flee by boat and military helicopter.
Even before the interruption to flights a steady trickle of would-be investors had been replaced by planeloads of journalists, arriving to report on the latest unrest.
"This is a serious disturbance. The whole political system has to be reformed -- and not just by having an agreement. That is an interim solution," onr international analyst said.
The catalyst for the violence was the collapse of a series of fraudulent pyramid investment schemes at the start of the year.

Economists believe Albanians might have sunk up to $2 billion in the shady schemes. They say the state, strapped for cash, has no hope of repaying investors without printing money and in doing so stoking hyper-inflation.

Amid mounting tension, the ruling rightist Democratic Party agreed earlier this month to give way to a "government of national unity", including the former communists. But insurgents, armed with looted guns, have set their sights on President Sali Berisha's resignation.
ECONOMIC OUTLOOK HAD BEEN IMPROVING UNTIL PYRAMIDS CRASHED
Albania's economic problems had been serious before the unrest, but the government was at least trying to implement reforms.
